items.standfirst: President Trump visits Alaska Friday for what the White House has called a "listening exercise" with Russia's President Vladimir Putin.

items.title: Putin praises Trump’s efforts to end Ukraine war
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and Russia's Vladimir Putin are set to meet on Friday in Alaska for a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine, marking Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. France24's Wassim Cornet reports.
items.content: US President Donald Trump and Russia's Vladimir Putin are set to meet on Friday in Alaska for a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine, marking Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. France24's Wassim Cornet reports.

items.title: Trump, Putin to meet in Alaska for high-stakes Ukraine summit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump and Russia's Vladimir Putin are set to meet on Friday in Alaska for a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine, marking Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Antonia Kerrigan and Alexandra Quarini report.
items.content: US President Donald Trump and Russia's Vladimir Putin are set to meet on Friday in Alaska for a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine, marking Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Antonia Kerrigan and Alexandra Quarini report.

items.title: Trump says Putin 'won't mess around with me' ahead of high-stakes Ukraine summit
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump insisted Thursday he would not be intimidated by Russia's Vladimir Putin ahead of a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine in Alaska on Friday that marks Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Follow our liveblog to see how the events develop.
items.content: US President Donald Trump insisted Thursday he would not be intimidated by Russia's Vladimir Putin ahead of a rare, high-stakes summit on Ukraine in Alaska on Friday that marks Putin’s first visit to Western soil since the 2022 invasion. The summit comes as Moscow made fresh battlefield gains and Kyiv warned of a “personal victory” for the Kremlin leader. Follow our liveblog to see how the events develop.

items.title: Trump says won't be intimidated by Putin ahead of high-stakes summit
items.standfirst: Ahead of his crucial meeting with Russian President Vladimir Zelensky on Friday, US President Donald Trump asserted on Thursday that he won't let his Russian counterpart "mess around" with him over conditions for a peace deal in Ukraine, as Kyiv and its allies push for the two leaders to find a breakthrough.
items.content: Ahead of his crucial meeting with Russian President Vladimir Zelensky on Friday, US President Donald Trump asserted on Thursday that he won't let his Russian counterpart "mess around" with him over conditions for a peace deal in Ukraine, as Kyiv and its allies push for the two leaders to find a breakthrough.

items.title: Anchorage prepares for Trump-Putin meeting
items.standfirst: France 24 correspondent Wassim Cornet reports from Anchorage, in Alaska, where US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin are scheduled to hold a highly anticipated meeting on Friday to discuss the possibility of achieving a ceasefire in Ukraine. Although Trump reportedly promised Ukraine and its allies that he would push for an end to the conflict, he revealed on Thursday that he estimated there was a 25 percent chance the meeting would yield no meaningful progress.
items.content: France 24 correspondent Wassim Cornet reports from Anchorage, in Alaska, where US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin are scheduled to hold a highly anticipated meeting on Friday to discuss the possibility of achieving a ceasefire in Ukraine. Although Trump reportedly promised Ukraine and its allies that he would push for an end to the conflict, he revealed on Thursday that he estimated there was a 25 percent chance the meeting would yield no meaningful progress.

items.title: Reporter's Notebook: When George W. Bush met Putin
items.standfirst: Former President George W. Bush and President Trump share little in their approach to the presidency. But they share a common journey with Russian President Vladimir Putin. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.
items.content: Former President George W. Bush and President Trump share little in their approach to the presidency. But they share a common journey with Russian President Vladimir Putin. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.

items.title: Former U.S. diplomat breaks down Trump's strategic objectives for Putin summit
items.standfirst: In the more than three years of fighting in Ukraine, Russia now controls about 20% of Ukraine's eastern territory. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has repeatedly said the meeting taking place between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Anchorage Friday should include no discussion of land swaps to end the war. To help set expectations for the face-to-face, "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson talked to Richard Haass, a former diplomat who has worked in several administrations.
items.content: In the more than three years of fighting in Ukraine, Russia now controls about 20% of Ukraine's eastern territory. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has repeatedly said the meeting taking place between President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Anchorage Friday should include no discussion of land swaps to end the war. To help set expectations for the face-to-face, "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson talked to Richard Haass, a former diplomat who has worked in several administrations.

items.title: Alaska's historic ties to Russia in the spotlight
items.standfirst: Alaska was purchased from Russia during the Andrew Johnson administration in 1867. War had left the Russians hungry for cash, and they sold Alaska for the equivalent today of 45 cents an acre. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.
items.content: Alaska was purchased from Russia during the Andrew Johnson administration in 1867. War had left the Russians hungry for cash, and they sold Alaska for the equivalent today of 45 cents an acre. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson explains.

items.title: Trump signals tough message for Putin on Ukraine as Alaska summit nears
items.standfirst: President Trump is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Anchorage, Alaska, as Mr. Trump seeks to broker a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson reports, Holly Williams has more on the human cost of the Ukraine war, and Margaret Brennan joins with more analysis.
items.content: President Trump is set to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Anchorage, Alaska, as Mr. Trump seeks to broker a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. "CBS Evening News" co-anchor John Dickerson reports, Holly Williams has more on the human cost of the Ukraine war, and Margaret Brennan joins with more analysis.

items.title: What do Putin and Trump each want from the Alaska summit?
items.standfirst: The Russian leader senses a chance for more international recognition, while his American counterpart hopes to play peacemaker.
items.content: The Russian leader senses a chance for more international recognition, while his American counterpart hopes to play peacemaker.

items.title: Putin ready to make Ukraine deal, Trump says before Alaska summit
items.standfirst: US president’s comment that Russian and Ukrainian leaders may have to ‘divvy’ things up likely to raise alarmDonald Trump has said he believes Vladimir Putin is ready to make a deal on the war in Ukraine as the two leaders prepare for their summit in Alaska on Friday, but his suggestion the Russian leader and Volodymyr Zelenskyy could “divvy things up” may alarm some in Kyiv.The US president implied there was a 75% chance of the Alaska meeting succeeding, and that the threat of economic sanctions may have made Putin more willing to seek an end to the war. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump tells Zelenskyy and allies he won't discuss territory divisions with Putin

items.content: President Donald Trump does not intend to discuss territory divisions and will focus on a Ukraine ceasefire when he meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin, he told European leaders.

items.title: Zelenskyy warns Trump: ‘Putin definitely does not want peace’

items.content: Ahead of the U.S.-Russia summit in Alaska, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said he had warned President Trump and European leaders that President Putin wants to occupy all of Ukraine.

items.title: Zelenskyy makes last-ditch push for trilateral talks ahead of Trump-Putin summit
items.standfirst: European leaders including German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy will hold a video call with President Donald Trump.
items.content: European leaders including German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy will hold a video call with President Donald Trump.

clusters.ai_summary:
• President Trump and President Putin meet Friday in Alaska for a summit focused on the Ukraine war.
• The White House describes the meeting as a "listening exercise."
• Putin's attendance marks his first visit to Western soil since the 2022 Ukraine invasion.
• Ukraine launched a strike on a Russian seaport the day before the summit.
• The meeting aims to discuss ending the war in Ukraine; further steps are not specified.

clusters.title: Germany urges Israel to nix West Bank site plan
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Announces West Bank Settlement Plan, Defying International Pressure
bullet_summary: Germany urged the Israeli government to halt settlement construction in the West Bank after far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich announced that construction would begin on a plan for thousands
Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank
Israel's far-right finance minister has announced plans to build a new settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, which he said would "bury" the idea of a Palestinian state

items.title: Germany urges Israel to nix West Bank site plan
items.standfirst: Germany urged the Israeli government to halt settlement construction in the West Bank after far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich announced that construction would begin on a plan for thousands ...
items.content: Germany urged the Israeli government to halt settlement construction in the West Bank after far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich announced that construction would begin on a plan for thousands ...

items.title: Israeli minister announces settlement plan to 'bury the idea of a Palestinian state'
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Noga Tarnopolsky reports.
items.content: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Noga Tarnopolsky reports.

items.title: Israel: Minister says plan will “bury” the idea of a Palestinian state
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Carys Garland tells us more.
items.content: Israel’s far-right finance minister on Thursday announced plans to revive a contentious settlement plan in the occupied West Bank, which Palestinians and rights groups fear will scuttle plans for a future Palestinian state. The so-called E1 scheme linking Jerusalem and the Maale Adumim settlement has been frozen for decades amid international opposition, including from the US. Carys Garland tells us more.

items.title: Israeli settlement plans will 'bury' idea of Palestinian state, minister says
items.standfirst: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank.
items.content: Far-right Israeli minister Bezalel Smotrich announced approval for 3,401 new homes in the controversial E1 area project in the occupied West Bank.

items.title: Israel appears set to approve highly controversial 3,400-home West Bank settlement
items.standfirst: Finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has said he believes E1 plan will ‘bury the idea of a Palestinian state’Israel appears set to give formal planning approval to a highly controversial settlement project for more than 3,400 new homes that has been frozen for decades and which critics say would split the occupied West Bank in half.Strongly opposed by the international community, the so-called E1 plan would extend the existing Jewish settlement of Ma’ale Adumim towards Jerusalem, further cutting occupied east Jerusalem from the West Bank, and further separating the north and south of the territory. Continue reading...
items.content: Finance minister Bezalel Smotrich has said he believes E1 plan will ‘bury the idea of a Palestinian state’Israel appears set to give formal planning approval to a highly controversial settlement project for more than 3,400 new homes that has been frozen for decades and which critics say would split the occupied West Bank in half.Strongly opposed by the international community, the so-called E1 plan would extend the existing Jewish settlement of Ma’ale Adumim towards Jerusalem, further cutting occupied east Jerusalem from the West Bank, and further separating the north and south of the territory. Continue reading...

items.title: Smotrich says new Israeli settlement ‘definitively buries the idea of a Palestinian state’
items.standfirst: Israel’s far-right Finance Minister, Bezalel Smotrich announced work would begin on the long-delayed Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank, leaving European leaders no Palestinian state to recognize. The plan had been coordinated with the Trump administration, he added.
items.content: Israel’s far-right Finance Minister, Bezalel Smotrich announced work would begin on the long-delayed Maale Adumim settlement in the occupied West Bank, leaving European leaders no Palestinian state to recognize. The plan had been coordinated with the Trump administration, he added.

items.title: Israeli minister announces plans for new West Bank settlement to 'bury' idea of Palestinian state
items.standfirst: Israel's far-right finance minister has announced plans to build a new settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, which he said would "bury" the idea of a Palestinian state.
items.content: Israel's far-right finance minister has announced plans to build a new settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, which he said would "bury" the idea of a Palestinian state.

clusters.ai_summary:
• On Thursday, Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich announced plans to revive the E1 settlement project in the occupied West Bank.
• The E1 plan involves constructing approximately 3,400 homes, connecting Maale Adumim settlement to Jerusalem.
• Smotrich stated the plan would "bury the idea of a Palestinian state," a view shared by some sources.
• The plan is strongly opposed internationally; Germany urged Israel to halt construction.
• The next step is the formal approval and commencement of construction on the E1 project.

clusters.title: Chinese economy slows as Trump tariffs bite; FTSE 100 on track to hit new record - business live
clusters.neutral_headline: Intel shares jump after report says Trump administration looking at stake
bullet_summary: 4% after it was reported that the Trump administration is considering taking a stake in the struggling US chipmaker
Read more: Intel shares up as US Administration reportedly in talks to take stake

items.title: Chinese economy slows as Trump tariffs bite; FTSE 100 on track to hit new record - business live
items.standfirst: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial newsShares in Intel have jumped 7.4% after it was reported that the Trump administration is considering taking a stake in the struggling US chipmaker.The potential investment, which would be paid for by the US government, would be used to develop Intel’s factory hub in Ohio, according to Bloomberg. It would also help shore up the chipmaker’s finances at a time when Intel has been slashing jobs as part of a wider cost-cutting drive.We think the Swiss economy will enter a short, shallow recession in H2 as the rise in US trade tariffs (to a whopping 39% for most goods) hits exports, while trade uncertainty more widely hurts investment.We currently expect GDP to fall by 0.3% quarter-to-quarter in both Q3 and Q4. Barring any revisions, this would mean that GDP in Switzerland will have risen by 1.3% this year, a touch more than the 1.0% recorded in 2024. Continue reading...
items.content: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial newsShares in Intel have jumped 7.4% after it was reported that the Trump administration is considering taking a stake in the struggling US chipmaker.The potential investment, which would be paid for by the US government, would be used to develop Intel’s factory hub in Ohio, according to Bloomberg. It would also help shore up the chipmaker’s finances at a time when Intel has been slashing jobs as part of a wider cost-cutting drive.We think the Swiss economy will enter a short, shallow recession in H2 as the rise in US trade tariffs (to a whopping 39% for most goods) hits exports, while trade uncertainty more widely hurts investment.We currently expect GDP to fall by 0.3% quarter-to-quarter in both Q3 and Q4. Barring any revisions, this would mean that GDP in Switzerland will have risen by 1.3% this year, a touch more than the 1.0% recorded in 2024. Continue reading...

items.title: Protesters gather in Washington DC as federal law enforcement officers stop drivers – US politics live
items.standfirst: At least one person reportedly arrested as protesters heckle law enforcement and warn drivers to avoid area as Trump makes false claims about crime levelsGavin Newsom, California’s governor, said on Thursday state Democratic lawmakers would move forward with a redistricting plan to counter the Republican-led map-drawing effort in Texas aimed at securing a House majority after the midterm elections.As he spoke at the Japanese American National museum’s National Center for the Preservation of Democracy – a venue deliberately chosen for its symbolism – federal agents, armed and masked, fanned out across the complex, led by Gregory Bovino, head of the border patrol’s El Centro sector. Local news footage showed a man being led away in handcuffs. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump makes false claims about crime in Washington DC as homeless camps are cleared
items.standfirst: President’s comments come after protesters heckled officers who stopped cars at checkpoint along busy streetDonald Trump falsely claimed that crime in Washington DC is “the worst it’s ever been” on Thursday, amid a federal takeover of the city’s police department and deployment of the national guard and federal agents in the city.“Washington DC is at its worst point,” Trump said from the Oval Office. “It will soon be at its best point.” He also baselessly accused DC law enforcement officials of giving “phony crime stats” and said “they’re under investigation”. Continue reading...

items.title: Kingsmill owner to buy Hovis in £75m deal to create UK’s biggest bread brand
items.standfirst: Jobs expected to go if competition watchdog approves takeover by Associated British FoodsBusiness live – latest updatesThe owner of Kingsmill has agreed to buy its rival Hovis in a deal worth an estimated £75m that could create the UK’s biggest bread brand if the competition regulator approves it, but also put jobs at risk.The deal comes after decades of decline in the popularity of the packaged sliced loaf, with Hovis, owned by the private equity company Endless, and its rival Kingsmill – part of Associated British Foods (ABF) – struggling to get out of the red for some years. Continue reading...

clusters.title: California Man Fleeing Home Depot ICE Raid Fatally Hit By Car
clusters.neutral_headline: Man fleeing Ice raid outside LA Home Depot hit and killed on freeway
bullet_summary: A man was struck and killed on a Southern California freeway Thursday while fleeing a federal immigration raid at a Home Depot, authorities have said
Reported by Reuters Top News, Guardian World

items.title: California Man Fleeing Home Depot ICE Raid Fatally Hit By Car

The fatal incident occurred in Monrovia, the Los Angeles County city nestled in the foothills of…

The fatal incident occurred in Monrovia, the Los Angeles County city nestled in the foothills of…

items.title: Man fleeing Ice raid outside LA Home Depot hit and killed on freeway
items.standfirst: Raid, apparently not communicated to local officials, one of several recently targeting stores in southern CaliforniaA man was hit by a vehicle and killed as he attempted to get away from federal immigration officers who were raiding a Home Depot in Los Angeles county on Thursday morning, according to authorities.Little has been disclosed about the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) operation that led to the incident, but officials in Monrovia, a diverse LA suburb tucked into the foothills of the San Gabriel mountains, confirmed agents had been seen at the store by city police officers shortly before 10am local time. Shortly after, Monrovia fire & rescue responded to reports of a pedestrian struck on the 210 freeway, a large interstate with four lanes in each direction. Continue reading...
items.content: Raid, apparently not communicated to local officials, one of several recently targeting stores in southern CaliforniaA man was hit by a vehicle and killed as he attempted to get away from federal immigration officers who were raiding a Home Depot in Los Angeles county on Thursday morning, according to authorities.Little has been disclosed about the Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) operation that led to the incident, but officials in Monrovia, a diverse LA suburb tucked into the foothills of the San Gabriel mountains, confirmed agents had been seen at the store by city police officers shortly before 10am local time. Shortly after, Monrovia fire & rescue responded to reports of a pedestrian struck on the 210 freeway, a large interstate with four lanes in each direction. Continue reading...

items.title: Israeli minister says Sydney Harbour Bridge protesters ‘useful idiots’ who fell for terrorist propaganda
items.standfirst: Sharren Haskel accuses demonstrators of ‘marching with terrorist organisations’ but organisers reject her claims and say people are ‘outraged’Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAn Israeli government minister has said the thousands of Australians who marched across the Sydney Harbour Bridge to protest against the killing in Gaza were “naive” and “useful idiots” for Hamas.Sharren Haskel, Israel’s deputy foreign affairs minister, also claimed during Friday’s interview on ABC radio that there was not a “real famine” in Gaza. Continue reading...

items.title: Qantas cancels flights at double the rate of Virgin, competition watchdog finds
items.standfirst: Airlines have also been raising fares despite downward pressure on costs from falling jet fuel prices, ACCC saysFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastQantas has cancelled flights at double the rate of Virgin, its main competitor, which had the lowest monthly cancellation rates of any major domestic airline over the past year.Air fares across major Australian airlines have also surged relative to the price of jet fuel in 2025, new analysis from the competition watchdog shows. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: The Apple Watch Is Finally Getting Blood Oxygen Sensing Back
clusters.neutral_headline: The Apple Watch Is Finally Getting Blood Oxygen Sensing Back
bullet_summary: Reported by Wired, Bloomberg Technology

items.title: The Apple Watch Is Finally Getting Blood Oxygen Sensing Back
items.standfirst: The feature was removed on select smartwatches due to a patent-infringement lawsuit, but Apple has “redesigned” it.
items.content: The feature was removed on select smartwatches due to a patent-infringement lawsuit, but Apple has “redesigned” it.

items.title: Apple Watch Blood Oxygen Tracker Back in US With Workaround
items.standfirst: Apple Inc. is restoring the blood oxygen tracking feature on its smartwatch in the US following a years-long legal fight.
items.content: Apple Inc. is restoring the blood oxygen tracking feature on its smartwatch in the US following a years-long legal fight.

clusters.title: Baby Shark: South Korean court rejects US composer’s claim song was plagiarised
clusters.neutral_headline: Baby Shark: South Korean court rejects US composer’s claim song was plagiarised
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Sky News World

items.title: Baby Shark: South Korean court rejects US composer’s claim song was plagiarised
items.standfirst: Ruling upheld that there was insufficient evidence of copyright infringement on song that is YouTube’s most viewed videoSouth Korea’s supreme court has rejected a US composer’s allegation that the producers of the catchy children’s song Baby Shark plagiarised his work, ending a six-year-long legal battle.The court upheld two lower court verdicts in favour of Pinkfong, the South Korean company behind the tune with the famous “doo doo doo doo doo doo” refrain. Continue reading...
items.content: Ruling upheld that there was insufficient evidence of copyright infringement on song that is YouTube’s most viewed videoSouth Korea’s supreme court has rejected a US composer’s allegation that the producers of the catchy children’s song Baby Shark plagiarised his work, ending a six-year-long legal battle.The court upheld two lower court verdicts in favour of Pinkfong, the South Korean company behind the tune with the famous “doo doo doo doo doo doo” refrain. Continue reading...

items.title: Baby Shark plagiarism case rejected by South Korean court
items.standfirst: South Korea's courts have rejected a plagiarism claim from a US composer who argued that Baby Shark, the catchy children's tune which became a global phenomenon, had copied his track.
items.content: South Korea's courts have rejected a plagiarism claim from a US composer who argued that Baby Shark, the catchy children's tune which became a global phenomenon, had copied his track.
